data.question: What is the primary method used to modify the flexibility of MOFs as discussed in the text?
data.answer: Post-synthetic modification (PSM)

data.question: What are the names of the MOFs before and after post-synthetic modification?
data.answer: Before modification: SHF-61; After modification: SHF-62

data.question: What solvent and temperature were used for the post-synthetic modification of SHF-61 to SHF-62?
data.answer: Acetic anhydride at 55 degrees Celsius in CHCl3

data.question: How does the breathing behavior of SHF-62 differ from SHF-61 upon solvent removal?
data.answer: SHF-62 exhibits 3D breathing behavior, while SHF-61 shows predominantly 2D breathing behavior.

data.question: What structural feature allows SHF-62 to avoid steric clash upon solvent removal?
data.answer: A 180-degree flip of the aromatic ring of the terephthalate ligand, known as the PSM-flip.

data.question: What interaction is identified between the dimethylammonium cations and the framework in SHF-62?
data.answer: A hydrogen-bonding interaction between the N-H group of the cation and the carbonyl oxygen of the amide functionality.

data.question: What triggers the change from 2D to 3D breathing motion in SHF-62?
data.answer: The steric clash of amide methyl groups of the modified ligands during pore closing.

data.question: Why does SHF-62 exhibit a reduction in the amplitude of breathing deformation in two dimensions but an increase in the third?
data.answer: Due to the ring-flipping mechanism that averts steric clash, affecting the dimensions associated with pore diameter and length differently.

data.question: What is the consequence of the activation-flip in SHF-62?
data.answer: It results in a larger change in the 3rd dimension (a-axis) which compresses the helical chains running parallel to the framework channels.

data.question: How does the post-synthetic modification affect the interaction between the two interpenetrated networks in SHF-62 compared to SHF-61?
data.answer: In SHF-62, the amide groups interact via carbonyl-carbonyl interactions following a 180-degree ring-flip, whereas in SHF-61, a 4-membered hydrogen-bond motif between amine groups on different networks is observed.

data.question: What role does the single-crystal-to-single-crystal (SC-SC) process play in the study of SHF-62?
data.answer: It enables more detailed structural analysis of the post-synthetic modifications.

data.question: How does the presence of different solvents affect the breathing behavior of SHF-62?
data.answer: Removal of either CHCl3 or DMF results in a similar flexible response in SHF-62, albeit from slightly different starting points.

data.question: True or False: The post-synthetic modification of SHF-61 to SHF-62 does not retain the continuous breathing behavior.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The activation-flip in SHF-62 is accompanied by a torsional rotation of the amide group out of the ring plane.
data.answer: True

data.question: True or False: The breathing deformations in SHF-62 occur distinctly in two dimensions, similar to SHF-61.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The amide group in SHF-62 exhibits site disorder and is not crystallographically characterized at full site occupancy.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The solvated forms of SHF-62 exhibit the same b- and c-axis lengths regardless of the contained guest.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The activation-flip in SHF-62 occurs without any crystallographic disorder.
data.answer: False

data.question: True or False: The change from 2D to 3D breathing in SHF-62 is due to the introduction of a new functional group through PSM.
data.answer: True

data.question: True or False: The breathing motions affecting pore cross-section in SHF-62 are decoupled from those affecting pore length.
data.answer: True
